DataElement.preferredName: PET Blood Glucose Prior To Injection Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Record blood glucose value measured before administration of imaging agent.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography (PET)  Blood Glucose Prior To Injection
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A simple sugar found in the blood prior to a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG) used in an imaging event.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A noninvasive imaging method that provides information about cellular activity (metabolic information).  It is used along with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which provides information about the shape and size of the tumor (spatial information).

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Property.preferredDefinition: Blood circulating throughout the body.:A simple sugar monosaccharide having two isoforms, alpha and beta, with a chemical structure of C6H12O6 that acts as an energy source for both plants and animals by reacting with oxygen to form Carbon Dioxide and Water, releasing energy.(NCI):Earlier in time or order.:Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot."

Concepts.definition: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

A simple sugar monosaccharide having two isoforms, alpha and beta, with a chemical structure of C6H12O6 that acts as an energy source for both plants and animals by reacting with oxygen, generating carbon dioxide and water, and releasing energy.
Administration of a drug into a location within the body; this can be achieved either through an established access or via a needle.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A numerical quantity which captures the amount of a simple sugar monosaccharide with a chemical structure of C6H12O6 found circulating in the blood throughout the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
